data.title: Learn configuration of FS paths for which to skip VCS integration.
data.body:
This patch allows users to configure paths such as `/mnt/` or `/Volumes/`
which map to network shares or other targets with slow I/O performance.
By skipping VCS integration on these paths, I/O is significantly reduced at
the cost of not having VCS integration and allowing Atom to at least be usable
as a text-editor when pointed at mounted network shares.

This is a attempt to mitigate some of the effects of #1766. Please consider this
a somewhat naive proposal for a solution that could use some more discussion
around ways to solve #1766. 

Feedback requests:
- Naming of the config variable
- The way this is wired into the git-repository-provider (maybe the `Project` or another location would be better).
- Alternative ways to stop Git integration on a per-project basis.

data.title: Atom Build and Install creates ~/.atom - Windows 10
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

After running the `script/build` process with specified install and build directories, atom still creates the `~/.atom` directory. I recommend this to be addressed, because **it inhibits the portability** of the application.

**It would be expected** that the `~/.atom` directory may be created when running the application, but not when installing, because it is necessary to change `$ATOM_HOME` environment variable to create portability, and in a portable environment, we cannot assume that the `~/.atom` has been created on first run.
### Steps to Reproduce

Atom is not installed, and your computer is in the state of never having Atom installed.
1. Using Regshot take a snapshot of the files of the drives and the registry
2. Run Atom's `"script/build" --install-dir ../atom-install --build-dir ../atom-build`
3. Regshot after build and install to notice that the `~/.atom` directory has been created.

**Expected behavior:**

The only directories created are the build and install directories.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

The `%USERPROFILE%\.atom` / `~\.atom` folder is created with:
- `~/.atom/.apm`
- `~/.atom/compile-cache`
- `~/.atom/.node-gyp`
- `~/.atom/packages`
### Versions

master@f1cf66
#### ATOM

```
Atom    : 1.8.0-dev-f1cf66b
Electron: 0.36.8

Node    : 5.1.1

visual studio 2015
```

data.title: Adding vim-like tabs to Atom
data.body: I realize that this would take a major effort to implement, but I'd like to ask you to [give it five minutes](https://signalvnoise.com/posts/3124-give-it-five-minutes) instead of rejecting it out of the get go. Please thoughtfully consider this: I propose implementing Vim-style pane splitting / tab management in Atom. In Vim, all pane splits are contained to a single tab. Changing the tab results in a having a different split configuration on screen which allows one to organize more efficient. Imagine I have the following arrangement where I work on the redux data flow of a react app: Imagine now, that I want to start tweaking css in two different files, without disturbing the current pane split setup. There's no easy way to do this in the same Atom window. The reason for this fact is that in Atom, tabs are created for each pane, instead of for each pane container. In Vim, creating a new tab would generate a fresh workspace with a fresh pane splitting context. **When we code, we conceptually split work into logically separate sections of the project, each of which involves working with multiple files at once: Data flow, Styling, UI components, etc.** Atom's current tab model sadly makes it difficult to map this way of working to the workspace. I think we would all benefit immensely from changing it.

data.title: Use application-level events to control updates in the browser process
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/about/issues/21.

Back in #10675 we [introduced a listener for checking updates](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/f884c987e29acef83a40164b681950a7fd8bf047/src/browser/atom-application.coffee#L307-L308) in the browser process without, however, adding the restart/install updates counterpart. However, we already expose both commands under application-level events (`application:check-for-update`, `application:install-update`), so this PR changes `ApplicationDelegate` to use those instead (and removing the unnecessary additional listener).

/cc: @amytruong @atom/core

### Description

Two Atom Helper processes get to high CPU usage after alt+tabbing in and out of Atom.
### Steps to Reproduce

For me it's not very clear how to safely reproduce this feature, but I'll try to give a description as complete as I can.

I have a large git project (~100k files) on my laptop SSD. The project is on a sparsedisk image (this was needed in order to have a case-sensitive filesystem) and is about 1.8G in size.

When I alt-tab to another application (e.g. iTerm2)  and then get back to atom for a few seconds the editor is unresponsive and these two Atom Helper processes go to 100% CPU. This behaviour was even worse before I deleted ~45G of data that was stored in the project folder (I can live leaving the data on a remote server, but it was nice to be able to test the code directly on my laptop...)

I'm including a startup CPU profile and two profiles during which I alt-tabbed to get the issue at least twice during the time spent profiling.

Nothing

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
The editor hangs for a couple of seconds
